title: Moon Landing

title: UCC Fee Referendum
description:
Referendum on creation of a fee to pay for the construction of the UCCOctober 1969, a referendum was conducted on the following question: Do you agree to be assessed by the University and to pay a special Student Activity Fee of $10.00 in each academic year while you are an undergraduate student at UWO up to and including an assessment for the 1974-75 academic year, on the understanding that it will be used in connection with the construction of a University Community Centre, or if such Centre is not constructed, that a refund will be made to you or the equivalent sum paid to the Alumni Association at the discretion of the Trustees? Yes/No.
 
 This referendum was passed by a significant majority of the undergraduate students and, as a result, monies were collected and paid into the University Community Centre Trust Fund.

title: UCC Fee
description:
Discontinuation of 1969 UCC Construction Fee to be replaced by a similar fee to pay for mortgage and operating expensesApproved Motion at Council:
 "That the USC seek to be relived of its obligations under the Agreement of Trust between the Board of Governors and the USC, regarding the University Community Centre, provided that a Board of Governors resolution be passed to stipulate that they will continue to collect a levy of $10.00 for the purpose of capital and operating expense of the UCC Directorate.â€ 
 
 NOTE: The USC paid this fee to the UCC Directorate, a governing body for the building on which the USC had membership, and used UCC space rent-free and without any occupancy costs, the heating, electricity, and janitorial services.

title: Star Wars released
description: May the Forth be with you.

title: CPI 1969 to 1985
description: Over the 16 years that the $10 fee for the UCC was collected, the Consumer Price Index increased 223% (averaging 7.61% per year). Had the fee kept pace with inflation, students should have been paying $32.34 when the fee was refreshed.

title: UCC Fee Refresh
description: UCC Directorate asks Westerns Board of Governors to abolish the existing $10 / student levy and institute a new (higher) fee, to be set by the UCC Directorate during the next budget cycle. In spite of the\is recommendation, the fee would not change for another five years.It further recommended that the Board of Governors ask the Administration to examine ways in which an activity fee would also be recovered from the Faculty and Staff of the University; the level of this fee to closely approximate that which students pay. It was hoped that this new fee would take effect on May 1, 1986.

title: Race Relations Policy Passed
description: From The Gazette: â€œAfter five years of research into racism on-campus, Westernâ€™s first race relations policy was passed by the Senate last Thursday.â€

title: USC Goes Smoke Free
description: From The Gazette: "USC President Steve Deighton has notified his staff that smoking will no longer be allowed in council's office as of Jan. 14, 1991.

title: USC Environmental Commissioner Created
description: From The Gazette: "The USC has created the position of environmental commissioner to help the university rebuild its weakened recycling program.

title: USC Stops Selling Porn
description: From The Gazette: "Western students vying for the removal of pornographic material from the shelves of The Picadily say the USC should take a moral stand on the issue and support them in their bid.

title: Reserve Fund Created
description:
15TH Meeting March 11, 1992 Be it resolved that the USC student fee be increased for 92/93 by the amount of $5.77 to cover the cost of establishing operating and capital reserves. Be it further resolved that this levy be kept in place for five years with the amount being increase by the inflation rate in each of the subsequent four years. The requirements for the reserves are: operational emergencies, capital replacement and growth and new programs. How the money would be spent would be the responsibility of the Long-Term Planning Committee.
 
 The rate of inflation Is based on the CPI for Ontario.

title: No More Late Night Run
description: From The Gazette: "The USC overwhelmingly voted last night in favor of eliminating the Late Night Run at its first meeting of the year.

title: USC/UWO Lawsuit
description:
From The Gazette: Students vs. Administration with the tenants in between The USC, which is suing Western's administration over the proposed expansion of the University Community Centre, will met today in court with lawyers and representatives of the university.Follow-up articles from The Gazette:
 
 October 30, 1992 - USC considered dumping Spoke 
 
 The Max would have been a student-run bar if the USC and Western's administration had agreed on proposed out-of-court settlements, according to a report released yesterday at Western's BOG meeting.
 
 November 4, 1992 - Business as usual for The Spoke
 
 USC president Scott Bradley says a proposal to close The Spoke in order to settle the USC's lawsuit against Western resulted from "an ultimatum handed down from administration.

title: Max Sinks in Red Sea
description: From The Gazette: "The Max lost $97,000 between May and August of this year, according to financial statements released yesterday.

title: UCC Fee administered by USC
description: Be it resolved that the University Community Centre fee be set at $22.04This fee was formerly paid to the UCC Directorate. Fee was $14.47 in the 1992-93 academic year. The increase was intended to address an operating deficit of approximately $250,000 per year.

title: USC joins OUSA
description:
After some debate and controversy, the USC votes to become a member of OUSA.From The Gazette:
 
 October 21, 1993 - Student don't know OUSA but seem willing to learn.
 
 Students at Western may not know too much about the Ontario Undergraduate Student Alliance, but they seem to agree Western should be a member.
 
 October 27, 1993 - Western student demands referendum on OUSA - Alliance tuition proposals not popular; protester vows
 
 The USC will vote tonight whether or not to join a new student lobby group, but Western student Jeff Powell says students and councillors should have more information and more say about doing so.
 
 October 28, 1993 - Western joins fledgling student organization

title: USC Day Care Levy
description:
Motion at Council to support the USC Day Care13TH Meeting March 2, 1994
 
 Be it further resolved that the two year capital budget be amended by up to $23,000 to provide the initial start up equipment for the drop-off child care centre.
 
 Be it further resolved that the USC subsidize the first year of operation of this centre by up to $32,000 to cover initial start-up overhead costs.
 
 Be it further resolved that these costs be met by a one time levy of undergraduate students for the 94/95 school year amounting to $2.75 per full-time student or part-time equivalent.
 
 Be it resolved that an annual levy of $1.50 per undergraduate student be made to defray the cost of undergraduate students accessing the drop-off child care centre by reducing the hourly rate paid by these students to approximately $1.50 per hour.

title: Changes to OWeek
description: From The Gazette: Big changes to Orientation Week proposed The USC will vote on a motion at its new meeting tonight to endorse a proposed new orientation governance model, which will point Orientation week in a new, shorter and more academic direction.

title: USC/UWO Conflict over UCC
description: From The Gazette: Admin lick their chops over UCC office - But USC cries wolf A bone of contention has developed between the Western's administration and the USC concerning the allocation space on the second floor of the UCC.

title: Final Report - Review of the UWO Act
description:
The University of Western Ontario Act is a provincial statute. It establishes principles of general application and designates the areas of responsibility and categories of membership of the Board of Governors and Senate. [It} stipulates that: The Board and the Senate shall review this Act within fifteen years from the date of its enactment.The strongest disappointment with the Committee's draft recommendation was voiced by the University Students' Council. Clearly our report does not meet their expectations which are founded on a different conception of the Committee's role and a different interpretation of its terms of reference. The Committee remains of the view that it has discharged its responsibilities in a way intended by the language of the Act and according to the terms prescribed by the Senate and Board.
 
 The Committee is compelled to disagree with two dominant and related themes in the submissions of the University Students' Council. The first is that student representation on the Senate and Board should bear a direct relationship to the increasing amount students are paying towards the cost of their education and the second is that the University must provide for greater student participation in decision-making by these bodies in the name of accountability. In the Committee's view these submissions are flawed.

title: Wave Burger: $5.75
description: BASIC BURGER - $5.75 This home-made burger made from lean ground beef is topped with tomato, lettuce, and onions and served on a Kaiser bun.

title: Part-Time Health Plan Rejected
description:
A USC proposal to include Part Time students on the Undergraduate Health Plan was rejected by Western's Board of Governors.The administration felt, for a number of reasons, that the
 recommendation to institute a health plan for part-time students is not appropriate at this time. The proposal before the Board is the
 administration's recommendation, which omits the health plan. The
 Committee agreed that the fee associated with the health plan is
 onerous and therefore could not support the recommendation proposed by the University Students' Council in this respect.
 
 The Provost elaborated on the reasons why the administration could not support the proposed health plan, principally because of the impact this compulsory (albeit opt-out) fee would have on students interested in attending the University on a part-time basis.

title: Western's Response to Double Cohort
description: Provost's Discussion Paper

title: Y2K
description: A computer flaw, the so-called "Millennium Bug," led to anxiety and the Y2K (Year 2000) scare. When complex computer programs were first written in the 1960s, engineers used a two-digit code for the year, leaving out the "19." As the year 2000 approached, many believed that the systems would not interpret the "00" correctly, therefore causing a major glitch in the system.

title: Gizmos Video Arcade closed
description: Gizmos Video Arcade closed, a victim of the trend away from coin-operated gaming and toward computer and home-based games.

title: Concrete Beach Renovation Commitment
description: The USC is looking forward to the planned renovation of the â€œConcrete Beachâ€ this summer. Long past its useful life, the â€œBeachâ€ is not only an eyesore but a hazard to pedestrian traffic as well. The â€œBeachâ€has deteriorated to such an extent that those located directly beneath it have experienced significant water leaks, causing both property damage and potentially putting building users at physical risk.
